In office
1 October 2003 – 30 March 2012

as Chair of the
UNICEF

She was widely known as the head of the office of the
United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees
(UNHCR) from 1991 to 2000

as President of the
Japan International Cooperation Agency
(JICA) from 2003 to 2012

Born
中村 貞子
(
Nakamura Sadako
)
(
1927-09-16
)
She was born on 16 September 1927
who became in 1943 the Japanese ambassador to Finland
she lived in the U.S. (she attended the Catlin Gabel School in Portland) from 4 to 8 years old
also lived in China from 8 to 10 during the Japanese occupation
She was awarded a PhD in Political Science from the University of California, Berkeley in 1963
in 1960 she married Shijuro Ogata
In 1965, she became Lecturer at International Christian University
After 1980, she taught international politics at Sophia University
until her departure to join the UNHCR in 1991
Ogata at the World Economic Forum on Africa, Cape Town, South Africa, on 4 June 2008
Ogata was appointed to Japan's UN mission in 1968
Ogata represented Japan at several sessions of the UN General Assembly in 1970
she served from 1978 to 1979 as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary for the permanent mission of Japan to the UN
In 1990, she was appointed as head of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR)
She was re-elected twice (in November 1993 and in September 1998)
and served, over a decade, until 2001
After UNHCR leader, in 2001, she became co-chairperson of UN Human Security Commission
In December 2000, and coinciding with the end of her second term at the High Commission at UNHCR
As of 2025, the organization remains headquartered in Geneva operates in 15 countries around the world.
In 2001, after the September 11 attacks, she was appointed as Special Representative of Prime Minister of Japan on Reconstruction Assistance to Afghanistan.
The Koizumi government approached Ogata as a candidate to replace Makiko Tanaka as Japanese foreign minister in early 2002, but Ogata refused to accept the position.
Next year, going back to Tokyo, the Japanese government appointed her as President of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) on 1 October 2003.
By adding loan assistance, under her leadership JICA became the world-largest bi-laterial aid organization in 2008.
She continued to work as president of JICA for more than two terms (over eight years), retiring in April 2012 to be succeeded by Akihiko Tanaka.
She was a member of The Advisory Council on the Imperial House Law on 27 November 2014.
The council met 17 times from 25 January 2005 to discuss the Japanese succession controversy and the Imperial Household Act.

On 24 November 2005, The Advisory Council's recommendation included female members' right to the throne including the right to be extended to the female lineage, and extension of the primogeniture to female members of the imperial household.
A 'Reception for Respecting Mrs. Sadako Ogata's Contributions to Our Country and the International Community' was held by Kōichirō Genba, Minister for Foreign Affairs on 17 April 2012, in Tokyo.
2001 Person of Cultural Merit
2003 Order of Culture
1993 Journalistic prize Golden Doves for Peace issued by the Italian Research Institute Archivio Disarmo
1994 Prize For Freedom by the Liberal International
1995 Liberty Medal
1995 Member of the American Philosophical Society
1997 Ramon Magsaysay Award
2000 Seoul Peace Prize
2001 Order of Friendship of Russia
2001 Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany
2001 Commander of the Légion d'honneur
2001 Knight Grand Cross of the Order of Merit of the
2001 Commander First Class of the Order of the Polar Star of Sweden
2001 Indira Gandhi Prize
2002 Fulbright Prize for International Understanding
2002 Honorary Doctor of Human Letters from Brown University.
2005 World Citizenship Award
2006 Grand Officer (Maringal na Pinuno) of the Order of Lakandula of the Philippines
2008 Grand Officer of the Order of Orange-Nassau of the Netherlands
2011 Honorary Dame Commander of the Order of St. Michael and St. George (DCMG)
2011 Medal of the Friendship of Nations (Danaker Medal) of Kyrgyzstan
2013 Band of the Order of the Aztec Eagle of Mexico
2013 Grand Cross of the Order of Sikatuna, Rank of Datu
2017 Humanitarian Medal Mother Teresa of Kosovo
Liberty Medal acceptance speech, 4 July 1995
In 1960, she married Shijuro Ogata
Ogata died on 22 October 2019 at the age of 92.

Ogata was appointed to Japan's UN mission in 1968

and served, over a decade, until 2001

As of 2025, the organization remains headquartered in Geneva operates in 15 countries around the world.
In 2001, after the September 11 attacks, she was appointed as Special Representative of Prime Minister of Japan on Reconstruction Assistance to Afghanistan.
The Koizumi government approached Ogata as a candidate to replace Makiko Tanaka as Japanese foreign minister in early 2002, but Ogata refused to accept the position.
Next year, going back to Tokyo, the Japanese government appointed her as President of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) on 1 October 2003.

organizations.name: RET International
quotes: Ogata announced the launch of RET International in Geneva, Switzerland.

organizations.name: Refugee Education Trust
quotes: The organization, whose initials stood for Refugee Education Trust, would be devoted to secondary education for refugees as Ogata saw this as a critical gap in need of a solution.

organizations.name: UN Refugee Agency
quotes: Ogata’s vision for RET was to bridge a massive gap she had witnessed during her tenure as the head of the UN Refugee Agency, specifically in education for youth.

quotes: It has worked directly with a number of UN agencies over the years, including UNHCR, as well as governments, and private foundations to provide opportunities to vulnerable communities.

Ogata announced the launch of RET International in Geneva, Switzerland.
In 2001, after the September 11 attacks, she was appointed as Special Representative of Prime Minister of Japan on Reconstruction Assistance to Afghanistan.
Next year, going back to Tokyo, the Japanese government appointed her as President of the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) on 1 October 2003.
By adding loan assistance, under her leadership JICA became the world-largest bi-laterial aid organization in 2008.
She continued to work as president of JICA for more than two terms (over eight years), retiring in April 2012 to be succeeded by Akihiko Tanaka.
She was a member of The Advisory Council on the Imperial House Law on 27 November 2014.
The council met 17 times from 25 January 2005 to discuss the Japanese succession controversy and the Imperial Household Act.

On 24 November 2005, The Advisory Council's recommendation included female members' right to the throne including the right to be extended to the female lineage, and extension of the primogeniture to female members of the imperial household.
A 'Reception for Respecting Mrs. Sadako Ogata's Contributions to Our Country and the International Community' was held by Kōichirō Genba, Minister for Foreign Affairs on 17 April 2012, in Tokyo.
